channel.title: Math Lacome on Math Lacome
channel.description: Recent content in Math Lacome on Math Lacome

item.title: Readiness or Between-player normalisation
item.description:
We (Martin Buchheit, Ben M. Simpson & me) recently published a paper dealing with monitoring training status with GPS. If this paper, we argue that “Since player activity patterns are more heavily influenced by contextual variables (e.g. rules, coaches’ interventions, scoreline, drills used) than players’ current fitness status 1, locomotor-related variables (level 1 and 2) may not be the most appropriate to directly monitor players’ training status.”

We proposed that player activity normalisation relative to the mean or median of the team (or a sub-group of player) could be another way to look at the data. Indeed, changes in content for a given day will less likely affect this new variable than overall total distance or high speed running. As soon as you get a sufficient amount of data (let’s said 2 months for one player), insights into players’ fitness and/or early signs of fatigue can be gained while following the trends of these normalised data over several consecutive training days.

Have a look at how simple is it to build similar model to start grabbing information on players.

We need to load the good library into R - simple work, we only need tidyverse to work around the database and openxlsx to load our .xls file where we store the data.

library("tidyverse")       
library("readxl")

Let’s upload the data into R

Master <- read_excel("C:/Users/mlacome/Documents/0_Blog (to keep)/Readiness-blog.xlsx", sheet="Data")
head(Master,10)
## # A tibble: 10 x 7
##    `Pos. Grp` `Drill Category` Date                Code    Id_Player
##    <chr>      <chr>            <dttm>              <chr>   <chr>    
##  1 AM         Session          2014-06-30 00:00:00 Session P2       
##  2 AM         WU               2014-06-30 00:00:00 WU      P2       
##  3 AM         WU               2014-06-30 00:00:00 WU      P2       
##  4 AM         Ph               2014-06-30 00:00:00 Ph      P2       
##  5 AM         Po               2014-06-30 00:00:00 Po      P2       
##  6 CD         Session          2014-06-30 00:00:00 Session P3       
##  7 CD         WU               2014-06-30 00:00:00 WU      P3       
##  8 CD         WU               2014-06-30 00:00:00 WU      P3       
##  9 CD         Ph               2014-06-30 00:00:00 Ph      P3       
## 10 CD         Po               2014-06-30 00:00:00 Po      P3       
## # ... with 2 more variables: VMAV_min <dbl>, MechW_min <dbl>

So, now we can see how my database if done. It is a rectangular base with 1 column for position group, one for the drill category, one for the date, the Player name or Id and my GPS variables - I choose only the distance covered above the maximal aerobic velocity and mechanical work.

For this first exemple, I will look at normalisation to the team only, so I won’t select my first column. For our model, as the number of players is highly variable and generally less than 20 for the majority of the drills, data is normalised against the median value rather than the mean because it better represents the central tendency in a small population.

Master_ReadiGroup <- Master %>%
  dplyr::select(-`Pos. Grp`) %>%
  # I'm filtering only Possession and Game simulation - I don't want Tactical and Physical drills #
  dplyr::filter(`Drill Category` == "Po" | `Drill Category` == "GS") %>%
  dplyr::group_by(Date, `Drill Category`) %>%
  dplyr::summarize(Med_MAV = median(VMAV_min, na.rm=TRUE),
                   Med_MechW = median(MechW_min, na.rm=TRUE))

head(Master_ReadiGroup,10)
## # A tibble: 10 x 4
## # Groups:   Date [8]
##    Date                `Drill Category` Med_MAV Med_MechW
##    <dttm>              <chr>              <dbl>     <dbl>
##  1 2014-06-30 00:00:00 Po                  7.04     0.858
##  2 2014-07-01 00:00:00 Po                  8.74     0.812
##  3 2014-07-02 00:00:00 Po                  3.82     0.687
##  4 2014-07-03 00:00:00 Po                  9.28     0.838
##  5 2014-07-04 00:00:00 GS                  6.22     0.515
##  6 2014-07-04 00:00:00 Po                 11.6      0.841
##  7 2014-07-05 00:00:00 GS                  5.91     0.804
##  8 2014-07-05 00:00:00 Po                  2.32     0.575
##  9 2014-07-06 00:00:00 GS                  8.04     0.797
## 10 2014-07-07 00:00:00 GS                  3.96     0.459

Now, for each drill, each day, we have the median of the group for Distance above MAV & MechW.
We can do the same operation to get the standard deviation (SD), but I prefer to set the SD of the drills to the average SD for each drills (Possessions (Po) & game simulations (GS). When you have a small number of players or outliers, SD can vary a lot and cause trouble for the normalisation. Saying that, we can move onto the normalisation of player’s activity.

Master_Readi <- Master %>%
  dplyr::select(-`Pos. Grp`) %>%
  dplyr::filter(`Drill Category` == "Po" | `Drill Category` == "GS") %>%
  ### I join the Master_ReadiGroup containing Median values w/ a Left Join ###
  left_join(Master_ReadiGroup, by = c("Drill Category", "Date")) %>%
  ### I standardise everything w/ Readi = (Value - median) / pre fixed drill SD #
  dplyr::mutate(Readi_MAV = (VMAV_min - Med_MAV)/ifelse(`Drill Category` == "Po",3.4, 4.2),
                Readi_MechW = (MechW_min - Med_MechW)/ifelse(`Drill Category` == "Po",0.22, 0.23))

Then, we have 2 options - We are happy to stop here, with players’ activities normalised to the median of the group. Or, we can start to track this number over time and look for changes in trends. One issue we could face stopping now is that some players might have more variations (noise) than others due to their positionnal role or playing profile. So how can I compare a drop of 5% in one players with a 7% in another one? That’s were I recommend (might I’m wrong?) to normalised again the data, but this time, based on the player individual mean & SD over time.

Mean_Readi_Player <- Master_Readi %>%
  dplyr::select(Id_Player, `Drill Category`, Readi_MAV, Readi_MechW) %>%
  # Here we group our data by Player and Drills (Po or Gs)
  dplyr::group_by(Id_Player, `Drill Category`) %>%
  dplyr::summarize(Mean_Readi_MAV = mean(Readi_MAV, na.rm=TRUE),
                   Mean_Readi_MechW = mean(Readi_MechW, na.rm=TRUE),
                   SD_Readi_MAV = sd(Readi_MAV, na.rm=TRUE),
                   SD_Readi_MechW = sd(Readi_MechW, na.rm=TRUE))

# Same operation - left join the mean & SD in the former Master_Readi & standardise.
Readiness_Final <- Master_Readi %>%
# Left join by Id_Player AND Drill category to have the appropriate mean & SD for each player.
  left_join(Mean_Readi_Player, by = c("Id_Player", "Drill Category")) %>%
  dplyr::mutate(Readiness_MAV = (Readi_MAV - Mean_Readi_MAV) / SD_Readi_MAV,
                Readiness_MechW = (Readi_MechW - Mean_Readi_MechW) / SD_Readi_MechW) %>%
# In the end, I only want 1 value by day, so I group_by Date & summarise.
  group_by(Id_Player, Date) %>%
  summarise(Readi_MAV = mean(Readiness_MAV),
            Readi_MechW = mean(Readiness_MechW))

head(Readiness_Final, 10)
## # A tibble: 10 x 4
## # Groups:   Id_Player [2]
##    Id_Player Date                Readi_MAV Readi_MechW
##    <chr>     <dttm>                  <dbl>       <dbl>
##  1 P1        2014-06-30 00:00:00    0.222       1.49  
##  2 P1        2014-07-01 00:00:00    0.664       0.355 
##  3 P1        2014-07-02 00:00:00   -0.393      -0.642 
##  4 P1        2014-07-03 00:00:00   -0.740       0.263 
##  5 P1        2014-07-04 00:00:00   -0.0177      0.204 
##  6 P1        2014-07-05 00:00:00    0.399      -0.153 
##  7 P10       2014-06-30 00:00:00   -0.315       0.672 
##  8 P10       2014-07-01 00:00:00    0.741      -0.286 
##  9 P10       2014-07-02 00:00:00   -0.250       0.331 
## 10 P10       2014-07-03 00:00:00   -0.658       0.0622

Here, it was a simple exemple of how to work around your data to get more information about how your players cope with the training. You can go further on with rolling mean and look for trends but I will talk about that another time. In my next post, I will explain a concept a bit more complex where we looked at modelisation & heart rate. Let me know if you have any comments. I know that this code can be optimised and would love to heard about you and your solutions. Feel free to email and I would be happy to amend the code or post your solution online!

item.title: Welcome
item.description:
Why am I doing this blog?

I’m Mathieu Lacome, a sports scientist working in elite football with over 10 years of experience in team-sport. A part of my job is to think about how we can improve the way we are collecting data, what we can do with it and how to report findings to the coaching staff or players.

Over the last 10 years, data feeds increased exponentially. Today, after every single game, data providers such as Opta or Stats produce a large amount of data. Also, we, as practitioners, are collecting data daily, with training load collected with GPS to gym performance obtained from different tools.

Figure 1: From data collection to data visualization

We then store these data in databases that can be as simple as excel sheet to more complex and powerful databases such as Exasol. Then, I have decided - and I’ll explain my choices later in this post - to move most of my analyses into R and reports into Tableau software. In this blog, I will show what we can do with R and Tableau software in term of analysis or visualization to get better insights on how players cope with the training load or team perform. I will explain (and give the code) of the methods used in some of our published papers.

In this blog, In this blog, I will not provide an introduction to computer science, R code or data visualization. There are experts for that and I recommend you to look at the references I provide in each sub-section.

Why I use R

When I started my PhD and was analysing data collected on my players, either tracking or physiological data, I was using excel - as almost all student do when they start. After the 10th phone call or meeting with my PhD supervisor, I was ending with a Analysis_V9_OK.xlsx version of my analyses. 5 month after, after sending the paper and receiving the review, I had to delve into my analyses again. At that moment, if I didn’t carefully write all the steps taken to analyse the raw files, I had trouble to reproduce my first results.

Reproducible research refers to the idea that in “computational” sciences, the ultimate product is not a published paper but rather the entire environment used to produce the results in the paper (data, software, etc.) 1. While it seems normal the research should be reproducible, how can it be if even me struggle to reproduce my initial results! That is the main reason that forced me some years ago to move most of my analyses into R and try to document it. “R is a programming language and free software environment for statistical computing and graphics that is supported by the R Foundation for Statistical Computing. The R language is widely used among statisticians and data miners for developing statistical software and data analysis.” 2 R allow to process your raw files and document (using RMarkdown for example) the how and why’s of your different actions. It can be used to tidy your data, create your models and build your graph for publication.

Good ressources to start the learning journey:

  • R for Data Science - Hadley Wickham : Read the book, do the exemples, and share with the community.

  • Introduction to Statistical Learning - Gareth James, Daniela Witten, Trevor Hastie and Robert Tibshirani

  • DataCamp courses: Free (introduction) and then low-cost online course. It has been great so far for me.

  • EdX courses: EdX free online course.

Why I use Tableau software

Effective communication to increase coach buy-in is now one of the more (if not the most!) important soft skills to develop for sports scientists working in an elite set-up 3. With the rise of data visualisation tools (e.g. Tableau Software®, Microsoft Power BI®, Qlik® to cite a few), we are now able to display data in a more effective and engaging way for coaches. 4 Among these tools, I decided to use Tableau software for many reasons.

  • Instead of printing a 20 pages reports, I prefers to use 1 or 2 dashbords and let the end-users play with the filters & parameters.
  • In Tableau, I find the design net and almost all graphics can be done in it (e.g., this has been done in Tableau)
  • If you want to learn DataViz or if your data are not confidential, you can start with Tableau Public - it is free !

Where to start learning:

  • Andy Krieble blog and MakeOverMonday initiative.

  • Tableau software website

  • The Big Book of Dashboards - Wexler, Shaffer, Cotgreave

  • Practical Tableau: 100 Tips, Tutorials, and Strategies from a Tableau Zen Master - Ryan Sleeper

References

1 - How to encourage and publish reproducible research - Jelena Kovacevic

2 - Wikipedia - R langage

3 - Want to see my report, coach? Sport science reporting in the real world - Buchheit M.

4 - Monitoring training status with player-tracking technology - Lacome & al.

Photo by

Samuel Zeller
